What a lovely video😍 of the Paris of the East مدینة الشام باریس الشرق Syrians are not Arabs but Arabised Phoenicians, Arameans/Assyrians and Armenians. Before Arabisation and before Christ, Syria used to be part of Phoenicia. Phoenician and later Syriac-Aramaic (Suryoyo) and Greek were spoken here when it became part of the Byzantine Empire. Jews and Eastern Orthodox Christians lived here. No Arabs, no Arabic, no Islam here until 634 AD. During the last years of the Ottoman Empire in 1915-16 Armenians (not to be confused with Arameans/Assyrians) were sent into exile towards the Syrian North from Southeast, East and South Anatolia (modern Turkey). Many people identify as Arab (because of pan-Arab nationalism and they speak Arabic),  only are partially of Arab-Hejazi descent.The entire Levant: Israel, Palestine, Jordan, Lebanon, Syria and even Iraq and Northern Africa is not Arab in origin. These nations have all been Arabised. In essence they come from ancient non-Arab civilisations such as Phoenicia, Mesopotamia, Canaan and Amazigh (Berber civilisations).

Props to her, she's hot af and has a great personality, those two things are exactly what you need to become a rising star in the world of youtube travel channels. Hers is one of the better ones because aside from the standard video tour of the places she goes, she is constantly trying to keep you engaged by educating viewers on the history and the unique cultures of that area. The channel 'Bald and Bankrupt' is a great example of this, except he's a dude, but he's also a very talented and entertaining vlogger who never goes anywhere touristy always giving you the real truth of the places he goes...good or bad.

I have to say thank you! Thank you for sharing with us your travels to parts of the world most wouldn't even consider visiting. Thank you for helping people change their perceptions of places and peoples that are often vilified or shown in an otherwise negative light. I have always tried to challenge my understandings or beliefs of a place or a people, understanding that often times those beliefs are shaped by only one side of the story. For that, I have always wanted to travel more in the Middle East. As a Jew, I've been raised to believe that this is a region that would not welcome me, that hates me without even knowing me just because I'm Jewish (and I'm not even religious!). But watching your various vlogs and seeing the natural and human beauty that abounds emphasizes what I've always suspected, in that there is more good than bad, and more friend than enemy. Thank you for challenging my perception! I've had to subscribe because I am absolutely glued!

This is the dumbest thing to watch. We are stuck at work being paid crumbs by our employers, meanwhile the only escape we get is to watch people who have no clue what real work is in life, and who get to do this for a living. Stop supporting this behavior. Stop watching this channel. Ultimately it just ends up ruining the world even further... We don't need bloggers who are globetrotting the earth on our dimes, we really don't. We have a serious issue with global warming, this job is in direct conflict with that.
The world is upside down when this is your life, and all of us watch wishing we were you, secretly pissed off at the system that is holding us all back... What kind of rich family did you come from? Did you know that Damascus is the oldest inhabited capital in history and the world? Did you know that Damascus is the capital of the Levant: Jordan, Lebanon, Palestine, Syria. It is the richest city in the world with water. Did you know that before the war, Damascus was the only country that welcomed its brothers from all over the world without a visa and welcomed them with generosity and originality. Damascus, where Salah al-Din Ayyubi died. Damascus, which the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, called God's paradise on earth. The first murder in the world took place in Damascus, specifically in Jabal Arbaeen. Between the brothers of Cain and Abel, the children of our master Adam, peace be upon him. The word Damascus was divided into two words: 1 - blood and blinded blood. 2 incision and meaning incision. And its meaning is blood slit. Damascus was one of the world countries characterized by peace and love, but unfortunately, the war destroyed everything and crushed the past and memories

Greetings from Germany. Syria is a strong country because of its strong people, who has suffered so much because of the war what has been brought to Syria from abroad. This week I saw the German Bundestag on TV and a politician from the AfD told about that a big part of Syria is liberated, in Latakia its possible to make holidays, and some AfD members of the AfD could convince themselves about it. Then the German foreign minister Heiko Maas from the SPD said in a disparaging sense that only those from the AfD are able to spend their holidays there. Syria isn't liberated at all and the country is in turmoil. After the politician from the AfD asked if Germany would help rebuilding Syria the foreign minister said that Germany certainly do not help now to strengthen Assad. In my view that speech from Heiko Maas clearly said that he is also infected with the "Assad must go" mantra created by the US, later adopted by their compliant helpers. The politicians in Germany regarding Syria rely on sources like the White Helmets or the SOHR, which in my eyes are some other things, but not credible. Regarding the White Helmets the politicians rely on something they created themselves. Pretty smart, aren't they? Mmmmhhh.... in the case of Heiko Maas i can't help myself but if I see him then inside my head I do compare him with Joseph Goebbels (Ok, Goebbels had no eyeglasses, but in my opinion they look pretty similar). Whatever he resembles is that he also lies, especially in relation to the situation in Syria. You, Eva, are not the only one who proves that you can travel to Syria as a tourist, of course only in the liberated areas. If you would travel to Idlib where the so-called "moderate" terrorists are in charge then it would be an open-end story. Damn, I did want to write a short comment, but there is so much to say about Syria. Yes, it will be rebuild, with or not with German help, because (and that was also a new experience for me) I did never see so brave people like those who defended their country against terrorism. With love and respect from my place to the Syria, its President and the brave men and women from the Syrian Arab Army. 🇸🇾❤🇷🇺❤🇮🇷❤✌️

Sure, perhaps the individual peoples of Damascus and Syria, those not involved in the "crisis" involving chemical warfare and foreign militaries, deserve to be shown to the world.  It's true that the people and the State are not always one, no matter which people or State one talks about.  But to call it a "crisis" and to gloss over the murder of Syrians by Syrians is irresponsible.  To visit the country and present it without that context is irresponsible.  There's a reason why you're one of few foreigners allowed into the country, where none were permitted a short time ago: they didn't want anybody with cameras capturing the bombs, the targets, the civilian deaths, and showing them to the world.  They didn't want you to see the Russian military carrying out the strikes.  They didn't want to show you which rebel factions they were killing, the unaligned militants like ISIL, or the foreign government-backed factions by Russia and the US.  It's a brave thing to go to Syria in this day and age; it's a cowardly thing to not disclose to the world what has transpired there.  The people that experienced the trauma, those lucky enough to still be alive, still live with the wounds; some of those wounds are new, still, years after the killing began.  You're covering up massacres and war crimes by holding the camera so close to your face and yet saying nothing.  The victims deserve better.

"Estimates of deaths in the Syrian Civil War, per opposition activist groups, vary between 371,222 and more than 570,000.[1] On 23 April 2016, the United Nations and Arab League Envoy to Syria put out an estimate of 400,000 that had died in the war.Based on Syria's pre-war population of 20.8 million from 2011,[3] this represented approximately 2% of Syria's pre-war population.
UNICEF reported that over 500 children had been killed by early February 2012.[4][5] Another 400 children were reportedly arrested and tortured in Syrian prisons.
Both claims were contested by the Syrian government.
The United Nations stated that by the end of April 2014, 8,803 children had been killed,[9] while the Oxford Research Group said that a total of 11,420 children died in the conflict by late November 2013.By early December 2018, the opposition activist group Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) reported the number of children killed in the conflict had risen to 21,065, while at the same time 13,173 women were also killed.
Additionally, over 600 detainees and political prisoners died under torture by the start of 2012.
By February 2017, Amnesty International estimated between 5,000 and 13,000 people had been executed in government prisons, and thousands more people are reported to have died due to torture by Syrian authorities"

Western reporters often exercise lazy journalism by simply copying from previous reporters who are biased or have reported on Syria with an agenda. Christians, Muslims of all sects, Kurds, and Jews (yes Jews) live peacefully in Syria. It is a true natural melting pot. The government does its best to protect the rights of minorities. Syrian merchants and shops all celebrate Christmas when it is time for Christmas and all celebrate Ramadan when it is time for Ramadan. The war in Syria was the result of group of Arab oil rich nations Saudi Arabia and Qatar wanting to have passage to Europe and the Mediterranean Sea and to do so they wanted to overthrow the Syrian government and stall a puppet government to take advantage off. This also fit the needs of Israel, Turkey and few western nations who supported the idea, the plan and execution of that plan to this date. They wanted to replicate what they did in Libya. Today, it has been over (10) years and Libya has no central government and is in a state a chaos who's oil and resources are stolen by the same EU nations with penny on the dollar from the warlords who  do not know what a barrel of oil is worth. Syrians chose to fight back and paid a heavy price because they knew very well the consequences of the alternative. It is true there are some true Syrians who feel the government power balance needs to change. And it should.  But, there are also many with hidden agendas that are not good for Syria or Syrians. Some think it needs to run by Sharia law when Syria has always been a secular nations. Some talk of freedom and democracy but all their intentions are just to take over the power. The length of this war (8 years now) ruined Syria's economy, infrastructure, human and natural resources, but it also brought to light the intentions of the many so called "opposition" militancy to the Syrians. I spent 2 weeks in Syria only one month ago! I would strongly recommend anyone to travel there! What an amazing experience! People may think it's, empty and dead, but I have never felt so alive, nor have I seen so much life! Love Syria!

@M !mm! I am from New Zealand - and probably look as western as you do. Syrians seemed to be sick of war! they simply don't care anymore...rarely anyone bothered to ask where I was from. There are scars of war everywhere (bombed neighbourhoods, lost children etc) but you have to remember 99% of the country is in government hands now, of course there are check points everywhere but this makes you feel even more safe. They may ask you for your passport as proof of ID at check points...I was asked once for the entire two weeks I was there. Syrians are just normal people, like me and you! If you go just make sure you stay in government controlled areas and there is little chance of anything going wrong! I forgot there was a war when I was there! Also head to the mountain villages in and around Tartus and Latakia.... Amazing!

Damascus was the least affected by the war since it's where the government runs from and where the president lives. It's old, traditional, beautiful, and the richest families in the country choose to live in it (I'm sure you've at least driven by some stunning grand houses). The generosity is very real though. There's a saying in the Levant: "do good deeds and throw them in the ocean". Basically meaning that good things will come back to you if you do good things for others.

While Lebanon has a higher proportion of people other than Sunni muslims, it doesn't blend all of that quite as good as Syria. Syria is unique. You go to Damascus and you lose yourself in the vastness of everything.
Other places great for visits are Latakia and Aleppo. Aleppo is on the frontline with the rebels, and I wouldn't recomment going there just yet, and there may not be a lot to see yet, as it is still recovering. It was damaged beyond repair imo. One of the oldest continuously inhabited settlements in history. Hard to imagine all the beauty went away in a matter of years.
Latakia though, hasn't been touched by the war, and there you can see what you see in Beirut. Just people, of different religions, ethnic backgrounds, living comfortably with each other, in a more western manner. And you have the coast also, so you can enjoy that too. Syria was full of stuff to visit. Too bad this war destroyed almost everything.
